awd_titl_txt: A Transatlantic Institute for Volumetric Powder Bed Fusion
awd_abstract_narration:
Although the additive manufacturing (AM) industry is projected to grow at an increasing rate, one of the most significant barriers to additional growth is the slow build speed of most AM technologies.  The transatlantic institute for volumetric powder bed fusion (PBF) is focused on removing that barrier.  PBF is an AM technology that fabricates parts by selectively fusing powdered material with a heat source (typically, a laser) in a layer-by-layer process.  It is one of the most widely used AM technologies for building functional end-use parts, but it can be quite slow, requiring hours or days to build a large part.  The objective of this project is to build the research foundation for a volumetric PBF process that has the potential to increase production rates by more than an order-of-magnitude by sintering the parts volumetrically rather than layer-by-layer. This project is a collaboration between leading AM researchers at The University of Texas at Austin and the University of Nottingham, with matching funds pledged from the UK ESPRC, so it is expected to build a new framework for US-UK collaboration to overcome the limitations of current AM technologies.  Opportunities for international student and faculty exchanges, virtual institutes, and undergraduate research projects will enhance the collaboration and provide opportunities for international networking and mentoring. This award is co-funded by the Office of International Science and Engineering. 

The research moves beyond the current layer-based approach to rapidly create 3D objects in a volumetric fashion.  The research path for volumetric PBF is to deposit powdered material with a patterned dopant in a layer-wise fashion.  The dopant will be engineered to selectively absorb microwave/RF energy.  Once the layers are formed, the volume will be subjected to microwave/RF fields that sinter only where the dopant is present, eliminating the need for layer-by-layer heating and increasing build speeds.  To realize this volumetric PBF capability, fundamental research tasks are planned to build our knowledge of how dopants affect selective heating of polymer powder beds induced by RF/microwave radiation. Computational and physical experiments will determine appropriate dopants and concentrations and processing conditions for maximizing part accuracy and mechanical properties and minimizing processing time.  Physical experiments will also determine the best material jetting routes to deposit the dopants accurately and uniformly over the selective area and evaporate the solvent carriers quickly.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project is to build the research foundation for a volumetric powder bed fusion (PBF) process that has the potential to increase production rates by at least an order of magnitude relative to current PBF technologies, namely, selective laser sintering (SLS).  A patterned dopant is deposited selectively into a powdered material in a layer-wise fashion with the dopant concentrated in regions defined by the geometry of the final part.  The dopant is engineered to selectively absorb microwave or RF energy.  Once the layers are formed, the entire volumetric powder bed is subjected to microwave or RF fields and sinters only where the dopant is present, eliminating the need for layer-by-layer heating and increasing build speeds.  Microwave or RF radiation replaces infrared radiation, thereby enabling truly volumetric 3D sintering and further increasing build speeds relative to existing high-speed sintering (HSS) techniques. 

Initial experiments demonstrated that the approach is effective for fusing parts volumetrically with RF radiation as the sole energy source and that the fusion can occur rapidly (on the order of minutes for an entire part).  However, infrared imaging indicated the presence of hot and cold regions caused by distortion of the electromagnetic field by the dopants, resulting in geometric distortions such as curvature along straight edges and thickening in the direction of the applied field.  To mitigate these effects, a simulation-based tuning methodology was established for functionally grading (i.e., locally tuning) the concentrations of dopants to mitigate the distortions and the resulting hot/cold spots.  An example pattern is illustrated in the accompanying Figure 1.  The resulting functionally graded volumetric patterns were implemented physically using two distinct mechanisms:  (1) a hopper-based powder delivery system capable of depositing powders with different concentrations of dopants in different regions of a powder bed in a layer-wise fashion and (2) a binder jetting system capable of depositing liquids laden with dopants onto a dry powder bed.  Experiments demonstrated the effectiveness of both mechanisms for improving the geometric fidelity of the resulting parts. Example parts are illustrated in the accompanying Figures 2 and 3. 

In terms of broader impacts, the project has the potential to make a significant impact on the additive manufacturing industry.  Future work could include the incorporation of sintering inhibition dopants near the boundaries of objects to further enhance geometric fidelity and enable rapid production of functional parts in a matter of minutes with a truly volumetric and energy-efficient approach.  The project supported one PhD student who completed his dissertation and now works as a research scientist in an additive manufacturing research center and another PhD student who is currently completing his PhD dissertation and plans to enter academia.  It also supported several journal and conference publications, a special session on volumetric additive manufacturing in an international conference, and an undergraduate research project focused on translating the research into a desktop implementation.  The research also provided an opportunity to collaborate with the University of Nottingham on the implementation of the binder jetting system for fabricating parts. 


Last Modified: 01/05/2023
Modified by: Carolyn Seepersad
